narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Assessing relationships and parallels between religion/religious institutions and other institutions related to health or science. Thought deeply about their intersections and pushed ourselves to think about potential motives for the way religion, health, and science are delivered.

I loved the way in which this course combined traditional religious studies with the modern health and science movements. Surprisingly, it helped me develop my creative writing skills just as much as my analytical skills!
Various topics in religions and health
Critically thinking about the intersection between health, science, and religion.

I learned an incredible amount about how health, religion, and science are inherently connected in the United States. I gained many insights into the intersections between health and capitalism/white supremacy. I questioned my own definition of "health" and how that has been informed by the social/cultural values around me. I similarly learned about how to define religion and how religious movements have been an integral part of shaping the institutionalization of medicine and science. I learned that "science" is not actually without bias.

This was one of the last seminars I took at Yale, but I loved that I was still learning about different ways to write even until the end. Writing the primary source analysis and the experiential learning assignments almost every week was a wonderful way to stretch my writing skills and figure out different ways to write even at a time when I thought I had learned all I needed in order to write well.

The intersection of science, religion, and health. How science and religion/alternative medicine have fought to gain medical authority, various health and alternative medicine movements, the Prosperity Gospel, mutual aid, diet science, self-care,  and environmental racism, among other topics.

I learned about the intersecting histories of medicine, religion, and popular culture, and learned how to analyze them with an eye towards the crises of the present moment. I gained tremendous clarity about the historical roots of the strange medical-cultural-spiritual landscape we live in.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great discussions and the professor was really wonderful at aiding the conversation without over inserting herself. I also thought we had great topics each week and a nice activity to go along with it.
Overall, this was an extremely strong course. If it had been in person it probably would have been one of the best courses I've taken at Yale.
I really liked Prof. Musselman and the environment that she created for the course.

Strengths: Professor Musselman crafted the syllabus for the class so well! Each week, we covered a different topic, but the themes built on each other. She also facilitated conversations well, was extremely understanding about virtual learning during Covid-19, and assigned interesting assignments. I liked the flexibility we got on our midterm and final papers to write about whatever we wanted.

Weaknesses: None.

Strengths:
- Prof. Musselman
- reasonable work load
- compatible with virtual teaching
- assignments are very interesting and immersive
- class size
- good pacing (we always talked until the end of class)
- flexible office hours
- options for how to do the final
- meme assignment

Weaknesses:
- the Canvas set-up made it hard to know your overall grade or test different grades in the grade book

In the beginning, I thought one of the weaknesses was the reading materials since they were mostly abstract and theory-heavy, something I did not enjoy as much, but Professor Musselman did an amazing job of being adaptable with the materials. There was a lot of reading, yes, but she found ways to break up the discussion, keep us all engaged, and allow for breaks to get through and enjoy our long discussions in order to understand even the more challenging readings we had.

Readings were very interesting, reading responses and essays were at times challenging but rewarding, and class discussions made attending the highlight of my week. It may have been better to devote more class time to reviewing the material rather than having discussions, but I still enjoyed and felt I got a lot out of them!

This course encourages students to treat their lived experiences as a valid source to be analyzed and put in conversation with histories and theories. It covers engaging material and was a joy to participate in.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the predictable use of the breakout rooms every class made me feel much more engaged that if the discussion had been in one big group the whole time.

Zoom breakout rooms were done very well in this course -- they were used in a variety of ways, with interesting questions that facilitated conversation, and students really got to talk to everyone in the class. Check-ins with each student at the beginning of class each week kept students engaged with one another and made the classroom a space where we were comfortable sharing all our thoughts. Policies reflecting understanding and forgiveness between students and Prof. Musselman made this class very pandemic-friendly.

The biggest thing was Professor Musselman's ability to adapt and change up discussion each week on Zoom. She would have us go into breakout rooms for discussions, play around on online notebooks and whiteboards to write out our thoughts on the readings. She even at one point had us go on Instagram and analyze posts and make memes to explain a reading to keep us all engaged during the online format. Despite being an early seminar, I loved showing up and stayed engaged throughout the class period as a result.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! A very fun course that covers interesting topics. Workload is very manageable and Professor Musselman is kind and wants to make sure you can succeed in the class!

This was an amazing course whether you were interested in medicine, science, health, or religion. It covered some of the coolest modern examples of wellness and health as well as a nice survey of the history of these fields.
Yes absolutely! Very fun and engaging.
Yes! Take it if you are interested in any of these three subjects. We talk about a lot of stuff that's relevant to our lives, and the assignments and readings are really interesting.
Definitely! Hands down one of the best classes I've taken so far! Prof. Musselman is amazing and the topics you discuss every class is so fun and interesting, you don't want to miss it.
Yes, I would recommend this course to every student.

Absolutely. If the interesting course materials don't intrigue you, please take it for Professor Musselman. She was an absolute joy to have as a teacher, and so attentive to us as students not just for our contributions but also for our time, our stress, and our wellbeing throughout the semester.

Yes! The intersection of science, health and religion, along with various health/alternative medicine movements, aren't something that's covered in great depth in most history classes. Considering how major a role these forces have played in shaping the cultural, medical, and religious landscape of the US, this class is the perfect way to learn about an important topic!
Yes! The content is excellent, and Professor Musselman is a wonderful instructor. Take this class if it at all appeals to you and I don't think you'll be disappointed.
